title: Have you been denied advancement due to the lack of a degree? - Quora

response.answer_text: Intriguing question and from my personal experience it may have been the case of being denied advancement attributable to too much intellectual wherewithal. I had requested to move my day off for my four day work week from Friday to Monday, that was no problem. The problem came when I requested to take one day of vacation for 14 weeks - (I had more than enough vacation) in order to take Stat 235 (Measure Theory) at UC Davis. I did not ask for mileage from Ukiah to Davis not had I asked for tuition reimbursement - I simply asked to take the vacation that I had already accrued. My supervisor stated “He would have to ask Steve (my former supervisor who had retired) about it - two weeks went by no answer so I asked the Director for permission which she gave. I had no sooner asked the Director & returned to my office when My Supervisor stated “He had asked Steve about it - answer from Steve I would not do it the perception would be bad” I responded I had gotten approval from the Agency Director - to which he stated “If she said it was okay, then it is okay by me.” Even stating that he had me promise this would be the only time that this would occur - to which I readily agreed trusting Dr. Roussas's opinion even the first Quarter of Measure Theory would be sufficient to dissipate my conceptual blocks. To this day I am highly skeptical that he even asked Steve. I think he wanted me not to take the class so that he would not be without his brain two out of the four days in the work week. He supposedly quoted Steve saying something to the effect that the Analysts are unique personalities and something to the effect that one should keep them right where they are (an implied don't move them up). Paired with the other quote, I believe that I constituted too much necessary intellectual wherewithal and there would be no support given for promotional opportunities within the Agency.

When I first came home from Vietnam I went to a local power company to apply for employment. My skills, other than driving a duce n a half were minimal as to what would apply to civilian employment. I was set down and given placement and aptitude test. I was always good at putting things together and taking them apart so at the end of the day they placed me in engineering. I was then put into a advancement course where I would take in house classes at work. Visit other departments with OJT and homework with correspondence work to be mailed in and graded. This went on for five years and at each six month interval you would be required to take a test and if completed successfully with a passing grade you would be given a raise and advance to the next step. A suit was brought against the company saying it was discriminator to non white employees so it was done away with and they went to requiring a degree to be employed as no more HS people no matter how qualified would be hired. This place me as a HS grad in the unenviable position now being a second tier employee even though I did the exact same work as college grads with less compensation. No longer were HS grads given promotions and we were left behind. I worked as a power line designer for the next forty years designing and building power lines while my college fellow employees were given advancement and corresponding raises. The funny thing of all this is that during the nineties all the middle management of my company which now mostly included the college people who were advanced over the years were let go and what remained. Yep, the HS people who built power lines were still there doing the work and we were retained as an asset the provided wealth and function to the company. Most of the affirmative action, equal employment, college basket weaving grads were let go, retired or down sized out leaving actual workers in place. So, all being said I was able to retire with forty years, and I am still called in to work storm trouble when there is an emergency or hurricanes. All well that ends well as my grandMa used ta say. But it still grates on me that I watched less qualified people get promoted and raised in statues just because of a piece of paper that was for all practical purposes, worthless.

Yes. When I finished my tour at DARPA, I was in an excellent position to move on to a number of other jobs in research. I interviewed at Stanford and ultimately selected them despite the fact that I was not offered a faculty position. Early in my career I earned a MSE degree and was faced with the decision of what to do next. I decided to go for a second Master’s level degree, this time in Computer Science and related topics. Why? At the time, I was not expected to end up in a university research laboratory and did not want to spend the extra time and effort to get the PhD. I should also point out that there was a two foreign language requirement at the time and I was not good at languages - a mental block. So, instead of a faculty position at Stanford, I settled for a Senior Research Scientist position. This was not a major problem for me and I built the job into what worked for me. It bothered me a bit to not have faculty status, but at least I didn’t have to attend faculty meetings! I had my research programs (that I shared with faculty members), I had my students, and Stanford allowed me to consult part time. I’ve known people without a PhD who received a faculty position at major universities, but those were unique situations and individuals who were exceptional. If I had it to do over, knowing what I know now, I probably would have gone for the PhD. It is a credential that is valuable for the rest of your life, even if you do not end up in a university.

Denial of all kinds of things have been normal for me. It has been life experience. Once I was fairly easily upset about it. All that got was the initiating people felt justified because I was “unstable”. OK. Somewhere along the line I started to push back. All that got was justification to continue the denials because I was “unstable”. Eventually, I learned that: 1.) Bullying and abuse of others is a normal part of most other people’s way of life. 2.) Anything I might do was preordained to fail in achieving a semblance of fairness. 3.) I wasn’t alone. I learned very early on that I was never going to win any beauty contests or pretty baby events. I learned that others will take from others whatever they want to take and will be backed up by others of the same mind. And, not just me. In my perception, anyone who is perceived as a potential victim will be regardless of ethnic background. That is one reason I won’t support something like black lives matter. I see it as using one community of this country as an excuse for wealthy and well funded Caucasian individuals to hide behind masks to bully and abuse everyone else, including those they claim to matter. By destroying businesses and income producing opportunities for people they are denying others the dignity of supporting their families and communities. They are just an extension of my experience on a broader scale. My counter was to work to develop my knowledge, skills, and abilities. In my mind I had to run to catch-up with others in whatever endeavor I was involved. If I was awake I was trying to catchup. If I was asleep I was trying to catchup. To this day I seldom sleep more than 4–5 hours a night. I know I’m a workaholic, a habit I have not been able to even mitigate. Prior to getting my first degree I found it difficult to get work because I lacked “experience”. Eventually, I started to acquire experience and run into other excuses. I was told I lacked skills, lacked this or that, told I wouldn’t stay with the business, that I didn’t have what they wanted, etc. I chose to push on to get my first degree. My first degree, Agricultural Economics, had limited application in the locality where I lived, Nevada, so I was told I was “too smart” for lots of positions I applied. I was also told I didn’t have the “right” degree for the job. It was just another excuse. Eventually, I opted to ignore the degree on applications. I got a job in heavy construction. I really liked the work and was working my way up in the company. I applied for a position the company wanted to give to a favored individual. But, I had seniority. I got the position on a temporary basis and was given a two-week training. Some of the older workers told me normally people got three months training for the position. Following a three month hiatus I was instructed to fill the position full time for three weeks. I did. Because I had the mentality I do I was successful in performing the job. Because, apparently things were set up for me to fail, the management was caught off guard because the job was done as was supposed. The manager started to investigate and discovered not only had i a degree but that I had run for a political office. He came into the field, sat behind me while I was working, and never said a word for three hours. I had no idea what was going on, nor did I ask. I just assumed my work was being evaluated, which it was, and continued on as I had. After three hours he said in a statement, “You have a degree.” I sucked air. I was going to get terminated for not disclosing that on my application. I replied yes, sir. “You ran for public office.” Again, a statement. Yes, sir. “You are only the third person in this company with a degree. The others are in San Francisco. That explains why you did the utility man job.” After a few minutes he got up and left. I spent the rest of the day expecting termination, the next day, and the next. Then I started receiving highe level jobs filling in for other employees who were absent. I continued working there until I was injured in an industrial accident. But, for a while I was concerned I would lose a job because I had a degree. In reality, and relative to your original question, degrees are not necessarily relative to any job. Some technical degrees are more vocational training and are necessary to get your foot in the door for what might essentially be an apprenticeship program. Most other jobs are on the job learning where if you have a high school education you’ll do fine in the entry level positions. Demands for degrees are primarily to self eliminate applicants, and to identify people who follow instructions and jump through hoops. There might be a sub culture relative to politics relative to degrees, e.g., the liberal tendencies of some high tech companies. You might be able to get a job with or without a degree if you exhibited liberal compatibilities. That’s speculation on my part. If you exhibit individualism you probably couldn’t get a job there if you were heralding the second coming, degree or not.

Sort of. After getting out of the Navy I was asked to apply for a position with the Radiological Health office for the State of Ohio - this was based on my 8 years of experience in radiation safety in the Navy’s nuclear power program. So I submitted my application, went for some interviews, and waited. And waited. And waited some more. Because I hadn’t yet completed my undergraduate degree, and the guy who ran the Environmental Health Division (which Rad Health was a part of) acknowledged my experience and the recommendations of the guy who would be my boss - and of his boss - but he didn’t want to hire someone who didn’t have a degree. I waited for 6 or 7 months before the fleshy-headed mutant was finally talked into bringing me onboard - and then he swore he would never again hire anybody who didn’t have a degree. Funny thing - I stayed in that job for a few years and then got a much better job offer so I turned in my two weeks’ notice. I can’t really say that this cost me the chance to advance, although I’m pretty sure I would not have been considered for a higher-level position had I not finished my degree. But as it turns out, I wasn’t there long enough for this to be an issue. But - funny story - my second-to-last day there I was on a conference call with the fleshy-headed mutant; it was about a radioactively contaminated site in Cleveland that we were trying to get cleaned up. I had to handle most of the questions because he didn’t know anything about it. Afterwards my boss came up to me and said “I just talked with Roger - he said he hadn’t realized how much we were going to miss you until yesterday.” But that’s in the past - aside from that one job I’ve never had a problem.

Your other respondents seem to have had a unique problem of being overqualified in some way. Mine was the opposite. Perhaps mine was more in line with what your question was getting at, opportunities lost due to limited school education. For years I devoted myself wholly to the job of intelligence work, while some of my peers spent much of their time studying for promotion tests or doing school work on the job. At promotion time some of them, though only nominally skillful at intelligence work, were promoted in rank because of their school certificates and test scores. It irked me to say the least! I had been made Production Chief of 42 intel analysts due to my talent and commitment to the job. But because I spent all my time DOING the job and not getting paper certificates I was left behind. We discovered the reason why when the promotion board visited the unit to describe their selection process. The promotion board consisted of two Colonels (officers) and one Chief Master Sergeant (enlisted). The Colonels were looking to promote high performers, which made sense, but the CMS steered them towards promoting people with documented education to “encourage the enlisted ranks to improve their education.” Like they say about the Peter Principle, people are often promoted to the level where they are totally incompetent, then stay there because they can’t move up any more. Or as I’ve heard it, in any cesspool the really big chunks float to the top.

Shalom Very tricky question. Being denied with the qualifications I gathered during my work in the 1st place after finishing my 1st degree/studies was irrational. This place was the Israeli army. The job was: Quality control of all none killing equipment of the IDF. It means as from checking the specifications. all the way to its final tests. Now, the equipment were: Tractors D-9 dozers, through all kinds of cranes, fork lifts, air compressors, lathes, Anti gas area/space purifying equipment, wire ropes, welding rods, armored plats, Bridges to cross water obstacles like the cross of the Suetz canal during the 1973 war, all kinds of electronic devices that are used to repairs of all kinds of electronic devices and more of these kinds. What ever you imagine. Not tanks, no bombs, no weapons. no canons. no cars and or trucks. Nothing that may kill people. So, with such qualification I never had a problem to fit into any job I wanted. this is to teach you that never stop learning/studying as the more you learn the more you see how little you know as the technology spread all over and it is very interesting. I could write much more but this is enough for general overview. No, I am not looking for a job. In friendship Rima

Yes. When I attended shitty diploma mills (Wright State - PhD Psych and Fordham - MS Psych), I was restricted from higher paying work assignments/internships due to my forced academic standing. I was also informed by local associated employers (when I was seeking summer work at the time of enrollment at Wright State) that I wouldn’t be considered for simple work due to the lack of the official degree. I assumed a basic level of intelligence and professionalism from faculty members employed within the formal edu sector. However, after attending 2 diploma mills (Wright State - PhD Psych and Fordham - MS Psych) after being misled by breaches of contract and blatantly false advertising, I would have to say these ppl are complete idiots. When I attended, the main admins/faculty were: Wright State - Valerie Shalin, Deb Steele-Johnson, Kevin Bennett, Gary BurnsFordham - Andrew Rasmussen, Donna Heald, Eva Badowksa, Monika McDermottThese ppl should be outed and fired. Tenure DENIED. The programs were rampant with legal offenses. When I expressed concerns about the WSU program, my advisor (Bennett) threatened me against leaving—he said “No one will accept you, not after the Psych 105 Lab fiasco.” (See below links). I ended up getting an MS at Fordham, but the former/current faculty had obviously been speaking with each other. How low these idiots will go to save their own incompetent a$sses. Pathetic! The so-called research isn’t novel or insightful, results are mainly faked. and the writing plagiarized (at best). This is what happened in the program:Sue Donem's answer to What was your worst experience in graduate school? This is how you’ll get “paid” in the program:Sue Donem's answer to What are some unethical practices in academia? This is how stupid the faculty running the program can be:Sue Donem's answer to Do graduate admissions look at your social media activity? I eventually ended up getting a degree (via academic extortion) and ended up doing work that never needed the useless degree in the first place. I also found (during the program & after) that specific program requirements were not relevant/used in the job at all.

Yes, I believe no having a degree did hold me back from being more successful. However, I really didn’t enjoy going to school and at times found it to be very boring. I guess this is one of my downfalls, but having to take a lot of non-interesting courses and ones that I felt I would never need the turned me off to college. However, I did continue in taking courses that I wanted to know more about, and at 86 I am still taking course that I am interested in learning more about the topic, and really enjoying this kind of studies and knowledge learned.

No, I have not. But I got three masters degrees and none of them had any impact whatsoever on advancement or salary. They came about from the GI Bill, so no financial loss. But did have the benefit of more knowledge. The two best bosses I have had, one at Procter & Gamble, and one at PepsiCo, did not have a college degree. One was a department manager, and one a regional VP, who was there when PepsiCo bought the restaurant company. The P&G boss never got beyond department manager. He retired early as P&G’s retirement plan, which made even young hourly workers millionaires. The PepsiCo boss was removed from the position. His replacement was a friend of the owner of the company, who was the worse boss I ever had. He had no degree but knew the right people as he was an older man. I left for a higher VP slot. My advice is get at least a 4 year degree. If you don't have a 4 year degree you will not ascend unless you have a friend pull you up. And with the lack of a degree, it usually shows in lack of finesse and smarts. But, you never know, if you are a master politician like the aforementioned terrible boss, you may do okay until that connection leaves.

No. But I have heard of other people having this issue, and my uncle had it too. My uncle is 58ish. He began in the computer industry back before there really was a formal education system in place to train people, worked in the field for 30+ years, all with the same company. When his company was bought out by an Indian firm, the guys came in and started laying people off. My Uncle was the only one who knew how the software worked for the company, because he was the guy who wrote it. But, he was stuck because he had to train a replacement and then they were going to let him go. He had no choice but to train his guy, because he had no formal training and could not get hired anywhere else. he is now in the process of moving out of the posh neighborhood he lived in and back east to a crappy repugnicunt area. I also know of a guy who had trained as Cal Poly, who was hired in his junior year to work during the summer to rewrite all of the COBOL code the firm had into C. They had to start form scratch because no one knew the COBOL language.

No but my mother was discriminated against because she didn’t have a Master’s degree. She had to drop out of graduate school due to health reasons. Later she was a District Director in the Florida State Department of Social Welfare, served as the President of the American Association of Social Workers, was recognized as one of the top 5 local administrators by the Menninger Foundation, and helped our Congressman write the first Poverty Bill. But when she applied for a promotion she was told she would not be considered because she didn’t have a Master’s Degree.

“Have you been denied advancement due to the lack of a degree?” Advancement? How about outright, a job? I used employment agency’s computers to browse available jobs. I located an ad for a computer programmer which specified a 4 year degree as a requirement. A lady at the employment bureau agreed with me that my A.A.S. in Computer Programming along with 4 years experience should qualify as an equivalent. The employment bureau arranged for a job interview at the company. When I arrived for the interview, the moment the lady who was conducting the interview found out I only had a two year degree and not the required four year degree, she cussed me out for wasting her time and showed me the door. (\ I wonder what she would say today if she found out how high my IQ is, if that would matter?

Personally, no to me, although once I was not hired part-time due to the fact that I did not have a Doctor of Science degree and the title of professor (I am PhD in physics). But during the period of layoffs, people without degrees and titles were first laid off. This is due to reporting - it is beneficial for enterprises and universities to indicate more people with high ranks in their reports, although this is not related to the level of knowledge and professional skills. I knew one professor, doctor of physical and mathematical sciences, who did not know Ohm's law. He served as Deputy Vice-Rector for Science at Saratov State University

After having been rebuffed twice I decided to stay with my primary educational material , open source and library publications, It has actually served me well. Being an immigrant to America arriving without any English knowledge has in fact been to my advantage over the past 57 years, As I am writing this the established norm requirements that would permit me to attain formal recognition , at least on paper were superfluous and became redundant to what i desired to to for a living and opensource information is out there everywhere to be had at my convenience. And i have used it every every day whenever possible. At the very heart of my understanding is the absolute CORE BELIEF that IGNORANCE of any kind about anything whatever is a VOLUNTARY ACT.

Here in NYC, I have been denied advancement due to being the wrong sex and the wrong color, which was told to me confidentially by the boss. In short, New York City has long had systemic racism, but it is Black against White and today, it is favoring Black Women over White Men and White Women. Yes, that is the reality in the Big Corrupt Rotten Apple, despite the media’s propaganda and corrupt politicians.

Yes, both before and after I got my degrees. Certain jobs require certain skills and certain skills can ONLY be acquired with certain education. Employers prefer to promote people who have the basic skills required to learn faster on the job. As we all know, almost all complex tasks require on-the-job training. Employers often prefer to hire people who have the college required to gain mastery in 5 years on the job, and the college required so they can be rapidly adapted to other needs, at need, rather than people who need 15 or more years on the job, and would need another 15 years if moved.

I applied for my boss’s position when he resigned. I did not at the time have a grad degree. They hired a guy from Duquesne, and explained to me why I could not have the position. Then they hired two people to cover my responsibilities and asked me to spend 6 months teaching the new guy how our medical school admission system worked. After one week of this, I gave notice and started grad school that fall.

No, I have denied advancement because there were better choices. Now what made them better? Usually more experience. This is a very tricky question to answer. Some business hierarchies don’t want smart people with degrees. They want people that show up every day and do their jobs. They don’t ask questions and they don’t think. They see something fishy and it goes right over their heads. That is the perfect person for the job.

I was lucky to have been around before degrees became a necessity to advancement. So I have never been held back due to the lack of them. I was able to get by with having pasted experience and hard work. I even lectured for 5 years part time at a local University without having any formal education but I had the knowledge and expertise to lecture on the subject. Today I certainly won't be allowed to rise up from galley boy to a large hotel manager without any qualifications

I was denied many jobs and the reason I was given was that I was overqualified. I got fed up with the silly reasons. I decided to teach privately pre university and university subjects like maths, physics and electronics. I get a lot of mature students who have been denied progression in their jobs due to lack of qualifications. I tutor them for a year or two till they get their qualifications. Later on, they write to me to thank me and give me the good news that they have been promoted. There are people who can do the same job better than a qualified person. In fact, all you need for a qualification is a printer!

This can certainly happen. One useful strategy in this case is show you are committed and can acquire the qualifications sought. Look for a university or other training source that can be attended part time if your finances or job situation means you can’t go full time. yes a qualification may seem very distant part time but - believe me / those years are going to pass and you either will have completed X % of your qualifications or you won’t . Either way the time passes. In addition once it is known you are completing courses relevant to your goals … you just might get an opportunity.

At times, probably. But, I feel that developing my skills and learning what I needed to know, choosing good mentors has helpecud me advance. Not everyone can get a degree. I was a single mother. That in itself was a barrier in some ways. I feel that a degree may have helped to get higher paying jobs but, I did okay.

I have a doctorate, so that is not an issue. Not getting some gigs because of the degree also happens, the always irrelevant “you’re overqualified” crapola…I know I am overqualified, but I am here and wish to make a difference…if you can’t leverage that to an advantage, I will find someone who can… Blessings.

Advancements can be denied for a number of reasons - and often lack of a degree is used as an excuse - which I would say is short sighted. It is not a “degree” you should look for - but skills/skill sets, relevancy to the position and so on. Have I been denied advancement? Ofcourse - lots of times (!) … and sometimes I wanted that advancement. Life is not fair ofcourse - you pick up and move on.

Yes, when I was young. So I got as many degrees and credentials as necessary, but then, my name and physical appearance seemed to get in the way too. SO I retired. We still live in a world where who you are and what you represent to others, often poorly qualified others (including a “degree”) continue to be part of the inclusion/exclusion risks we suffer.

I live in a college town where some super talented people are graduating all the time. Employers can be choosers and demand a four year degree because competition allows it. While I haven’t been denied advancement at my current employment, trying to get a decent upgrade at another location in town is not possible without the paper.

Nope. Fortunately, I’ve never been in the position of denied advancement while earning my bachelor's degree, two master's degrees & two doctorates earned during my career. I have consistently encouraged peers & subordinates to continue their education as much as possible in order to advance in their careers & for personal growth development.

A degree is not going to help much in advancing in the trades. Unless you want to become a desk !manager type. I have met plenty of guys who make way more momey in a trade than some college guys. One must have drive also. Raw intelligence and talent clunts also. A degree isn't a golden ticket to the chocolate fsctory.

Ever have HR tear up a resume AFTER an interview? I was at a job fair and had a good interview with a manager who needed an EMC Engineer, It looked good until I got to an HR reptile. “HOW MUCH did you make?” she exploded; ”*I* don’t make that much and *I* have a degree! “ That told me something about the about the firms attitude - and I decided to look elsewhere. Oddly enough, my next job was a contract at a competitor’s lab …

As somebody who has been involved in this question, here is an input: Hiring a new employee is heavily dependent on education. Once an employee is hired, his rewards are heavily dependent on how well he advances the objectives assigned to his manager. His manager has little historic interest in any past accomplishments, including a degree.

No, because I was in the process of acquiring it. So, it never really made a difference.The bachelors served meanwhile. However, things nowadays are different, if you do not have a degree you cannot progress (unless you can attest that at the time of your professional assessment period you will have it.)

I was denied access to a study course due to the lack of a grade 12 subject. I now hold a Masters degree. But when I finished school I wanted to become a veterinary surgeon. I got kicked off the course because my grade 12 Mathematics mark was to low. It put my life on a total different track.

No. In fact, even without a college degree I got a job as a TV reporter in San Antonio many years ago. Since then I earned a bachelor’s degree from UMASS Amherst. An education is far more important today than ever before.

Not that I know of. It could happen, but it hasn’t happened to me. I have fairly good position at local technical university, being one of the few people capable of transferring human based agenda into digital form, so that people can fill their forms from home.

I have a degree, so no, but I have seen it happen: People start doing night school and as soon as they graduate, they see advancement soon after. Someone in HR or management hint to them that they won’t see advancement before they get the degree.

I’m working on a doctorate, so that hasn’t been a problem for me, but I have had people say that if they hired me for certain part-time positions they’d be scared that I’d leave in a week when something better comes up.

I denied myself meaningful employment because of having only a high school diploma. I plateaued in my job prospects because I lacked industry certifications. No more of that; I’m studying to become a systems administrator.

Never unless the position I wanted required a degree. In that case if Inwanted the position I had to get the degree, so I did. It is only right that I should be denied a position for which I do not meet the minimum requirements.

Yes. They said that hey would promote me, but they couldn’t because I had no degree. If I got my degree they would promote me in a moment.And when I got my degree and asked to be promoted, they asked if I had it in writing.

I did a job interview for to work with domestic violence victims and since I don’t have experience working with this particular population and no advance degree, I was offered $10 per hour. I wasn’t hired for the position.

Quite the opposite. I have been denied lateral moves due to my degree. In the US it is quite unfathomable that you might want the same amount of money or less for other benefits like flexibility or location.
Yes, due to not having a degree, being black, and being female. Studies show that women are more unlikely to get advancement and Black women even more so. It is what it is.

When i went to study my second degree i wanted to work a simple job so that it doesn’t distract me from my studies. I realised over time that having a degree can make you over qualified for some jobs so i shaped a different resume for certain jobs.
No, I haven’t. Probably because I had the requirements to advance and already earned my degree. I’d imagine they would deny me advancement should I not have the required degree though.

Yes. But at the time I was considering going into business for myself so that did not matter. My business was successful and was the better decision considering I didn’t like where I had been working anyway.

LIKE LACK OF QUALIFICATIONS FOR A POSITION? = inform your interviewer that you ARE NOW IN THE CRIDTING COLLEGE COURSES (have info ready to talk about) If me APPLYING for a spot that I'm not qualified for Sounds stupid to me, l am not that dumb.

Never in the private sector. I was a tenured faculty never at a major state university. Lack of a Ph.D. limited my advancement beyond Department Chair (which was ok with me) but not my salary increases as a teacher.

No. I held progressively better jobs because of experience and knowledge way before I knuckled down and earned my 3 degrees. They are just paper. Knowledge, insight and experience is what an employer wants.
I was told that I would need an advanced Engineering degree about five years down the line, and I got one. Promotion was not denied to me, but was denied to several others who did not do so.
Never. But then I had a degree in mathematics. It is kind of a hard degree to earn. So even though it was only a bachelor's degree, it gets a lot of mileage.
Never , I went from Warehouse boy to owner. Without a degree. Working on high pressure breathing air machines for public safety.
No I have not but I know people who have. Always best to meet all qualifications before applying for jobs that ask for a specific degree.
No. I chose that I did not want any kind of advancement. Neither in the UK nor in the USA. So I suppose you failed. :) Have a good day.
Yes, yes, yes, I can't find anybody who'll let me do brain surgery without that darned medical degree. Unfair.
NO, I have 2 degrees, one from the University of Indianapolis and Butler University. Just 2 basic small colleges.
A2A. I have passed on interviewing thousands of professionals over the past 20 years because their resume lacked a degree.
NO! I’ve always pursued education rigorously.
No, I am being denied acceptance because of irrationality.
